childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1951-1963

The smell of Bactine on scraped knees. The satisfying weight of a View-Master against your face, clicking through reels of the Grand Canyon or Disneyland. The creak of a Radio Flyer wagon being dragged across summer sidewalks. Your childhood had a texture that belongs to a vanished world—a world where kids disappeared after breakfast and came home when the streetlights flickered on.

At three, you were watching Howdy Doody in the Peanut Gallery, maybe Kukla, Fran and Ollie, your face inches from a small screen with rabbit-ear antennas your father constantly adjusted. By five, the Mickey Mouse Club had you wearing paper ears and pledging allegiance to Annette Funicello. You probably had strong opinions about whether you were a Roy Rogers kid or a Hopalong Cassidy kid. The cap guns were loud. The cowboy hats were felt. Everything smelled like caps and leather.

Your toys were simple and built to last. Lincoln Logs for frontier cabins. Erector Sets with actual metal pieces that could cut you. Tinker Toys for anything your imagination could construct. Mr. Potato Head arrived when you were one—though back then you supplied your own potato. Silly Putty came in plastic eggs. Slinkys walked down stairs. Play-Doh smelled like nothing else on earth, and you can still summon that scent if you close your eyes.

Saturday mornings meant the RKO matinee: a newsreel, a cartoon, a serial cliffhanger, then the main feature. You ate Milk Duds and Necco Wafers in the dark. The serials always ended with the hero in mortal peril—tied to railroad tracks, hanging from cliffs—and you'd spend the whole week wondering how they'd survive. (They always did. The same way, mostly.)

Your mother made casseroles with Campbell's soup as the base. Tuna noodle. Green bean with those crunchy onion things. Jell-O molds with fruit suspended inside like insects in amber. TV dinners arrived when you were three, and suddenly dinner could come in aluminum trays with compartments—Salisbury steak here, mashed potatoes there, apple cobbler in the corner. You ate them on TV trays, watching I Love Lucy, the whole family arranged around the flickering blue glow.

At six, you learned to duck and cover. The teacher said the Soviets might drop bombs, and if you heard the siren, you should get under your desk and cover your head. You practiced this drill with the same seriousness as fire drills. Nobody told you a wooden desk wouldn't save you from a nuclear blast. Maybe they didn't know. Maybe they just needed something to tell children.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers

Baby Boomer. The name came from demographers who noticed something obvious: soldiers came home from World War II and started families like the survival of the species depended on it. Your generation spans 1946 to 1964—roughly 76 million Americans who would reshape every institution they touched through sheer demographic force.

You were twelve when President Kennedy was assassinated. Seventh grade. November 22, 1963. The principal came on the intercom, or a teacher ran in crying, or someone heard it on a transistor radio. Walter Cronkite took off his glasses on live television and announced the president was dead. You remember where you were. Everyone your age remembers. It was the first time you understood that the world could break without warning.

Your generation grew up during the greatest expansion of the American middle class in history. Your father probably worked one job that paid for a house, a car, a stay-at-home wife, and two weeks at the shore every summer. This wasn't exceptional. This was just how things worked. Nobody called it the American Dream because it was just Tuesday.

You were eighteen when the draft lottery started, numbers pulled from a glass jar on live television like a deadly game show. Your birthday corresponded to a number that might send you to Vietnam or let you stay home. Some of your friends went. Some didn't come back. Some came back different. The war divided your generation into those who served, those who protested, and those who quietly tried to avoid both.

Boomers straddled two Americas. You remember the old one—segregated lunch counters, party-line telephones, doctors who made house calls, milk delivered to your door. You built the new one—civil rights marches, counterculture protests, Woodstock, the pill. You questioned everything your parents accepted. Then you grew up, bought houses in the suburbs, and became the establishment you once marched against. The contradictions are yours to own.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

An American in Paris won Best Picture the year you were born, Gene Kelly dancing through soundstages dressed like France. The music was still pre-rock: Nat King Cole crooning 'Too Young,' Tony Bennett breaking through with 'Because of You,' Patti Page asking how much that doggie in the window cost. Bing Crosby and Perry Como dominated the airwaves. This was your parents' music. Yours was coming.

You were three when Elvis Presley walked into Sun Studios in Memphis. Five when he appeared on Ed Sullivan, shot from the waist up because his hips were considered too dangerous for American living rooms. Seven when Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and the Big Bopper died in a plane crash in Iowa—'the day the music died,' Don McLean would call it. Rock and roll was young enough to lose its pioneers while you were still in grade school.

Television was the revolution. I Love Lucy premiered the year you were born, teaching America to laugh at a redhead and her Cuban bandleader husband. You grew up with Dragnet's 'just the facts, ma'am,' The Lone Ranger's silver bullets, Father Knows Best's suburban certainties. You watched the Army-McCarthy hearings at three and learned that adults on television could be cruel. You watched Elvis at five and learned they could also be dangerous.

By high school, everything had changed. The Beatles appeared on Ed Sullivan when you were twelve, and 73 million people watched. You either wanted to be them or date them. Bob Dylan went electric at Newport when you were fourteen, and folk purists booed while the future applauded. The Supremes, the Rolling Stones, the Beach Boys—AM radio became the soundtrack of your adolescence, and you knew every word to every song because everyone was listening to the same stations.

Your teenage years collided with counterculture. At sixteen, the Summer of Love. At eighteen, Woodstock—you either went, wish you'd gone, or tell people you went. Hair opened on Broadway. Easy Rider hit theaters. 2001: A Space Odyssey made audiences wonder if they were watching the future or just really high. The culture wasn't just entertainment anymore. It was a declaration of values, a generational divide made visible in hair length and hemlines.

The pop culture of your youth was communal in ways nothing has been since. Three networks. One radio dial. Everyone saw the same shows, heard the same songs, shared the same references. When Johnny Carson made a joke, the whole country got it. When the Beatles broke up, the whole country mourned. There were no algorithms, no niches, no personalized feeds. Just a shared cultural experience that actually was shared.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

UNIVAC I became the first commercial computer in America the year you were born—a machine the size of a room that cost a million dollars and could do less than a calculator you'd eventually buy for five bucks. Color television was introduced in 1951, though almost nobody had one. Your family probably had a black-and-white Philco or RCA, furniture-sized with a screen you could barely see from the couch.

At three, the transistor radio arrived, small enough to fit in your pocket, and suddenly music could go anywhere you did. At six, the first transatlantic telephone cable was completed—before that, calls across the ocean went by radio and cost a fortune. At seven, Sputnik beeped across the night sky, and America panicked that the Soviets were winning the space race. Your math homework suddenly mattered to national security.

Your childhood technology was mechanical, analog, physical. You probably had a party-line telephone—pick up the receiver and sometimes your neighbors were already talking. Rotary dials that took forever to spin back. Busy signals that meant try again later. Long-distance calls were expensive enough that you saved them for emergencies and holidays. Three minutes to wish Grandma happy birthday, then hand the phone to your sister.

You were eighteen when Apollo 11 landed on the moon. July 20, 1969. You watched it live on television, grainy footage from 238,000 miles away, and Neil Armstrong stepped onto the surface while the whole world held its breath. Six hundred million people watched. It felt like anything was possible. The future your childhood promised had arrived.

At twenty, the first ARPANET message was sent—the ancestor of the internet you'd eventually use. At twenty-two, the first email. At twenty-six, Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak sold the Apple II. You were in your thirties when the IBM PC arrived, your forties when the World Wide Web launched. You learned to type on typewriters, transitioned to word processors, figured out email reluctantly, and watched your grandchildren grow up with phones in their hands.

Your relationship with technology is earned, not assumed. You remember when there wasn't any. You can write in cursive, read a paper map, do arithmetic without a calculator, remember phone numbers, navigate without GPS. You've watched society become dependent on devices that didn't exist when you were raising children. You're not impressed. You're the last generation that knows, from direct experience, that life worked fine without any of this.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born during the Korean War, which nobody called a war—they called it a 'police action,' as if that made the dying less real. Your father might have served. Your uncles might have. It ended when you were two, in a stalemate that pleased nobody, and became the 'Forgotten War' because it was sandwiched between World War II's heroism and Vietnam's controversy.

At three, the Supreme Court ruled on Brown v. Board of Education: separate was not equal, segregation must end. At four, Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat on a Montgomery bus. At six, federal troops escorted nine Black students into Little Rock Central High School while mobs screamed outside. The civil rights movement was the moral backdrop of your childhood. Where you stood depended on where you lived.

At twelve, you experienced the moment that would define your generation: President Kennedy's assassination. Your generation's detailed memory of that day—the intercom announcement, the teachers crying, the four days of continuous television coverage—is covered in your generational identity. What matters historically is simpler: America lost its young president, and the optimism of the early 1960s fractured.

The sixties unraveled fast after that. At fourteen, Watts burned. At sixteen, Newark and Detroit. At seventeen, Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis—April 4, 1968. Two months later, Robert Kennedy was shot in Los Angeles. Tanks in American streets. Cities on fire. The country your parents built seemed to be tearing itself apart, and you were coming of age in the rubble.

At eighteen, men walked on the moon. That was July. In December, the draft lottery aired on television—birthdays drawn from a glass jar, numbers assigned to determine who would go to Vietnam. Your date of birth became a ticket in a deadly raffle. If your number was low, you were going unless you found a way out. College deferments. Medical exemptions. Canada. The war became personal in a way that abstract patriotism couldn't match.

At twenty-three, you watched Watergate unfold—the hearings, the tapes, Nixon's resignation. At twenty-nine, the Iran hostage crisis. At thirty-eight, the Berlin Wall fell, ending the Cold War that had shaped your entire life. At fifty, terrorists flew planes into buildings, and the certainty you'd felt since the Wall fell evaporated. At fifty-seven, the economy collapsed. At sixty-nine, a pandemic killed more Americans than any war since the Civil War. You've lived through so much history that the word 'unprecedented' has lost all meaning.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce around 1973—not the best timing. The OPEC oil embargo sent gas prices soaring. Nixon resigned. Stagflation made economists question everything they thought they knew. But you were young, and young people adapt. You took the jobs available and figured the rest would sort itself out. For your generation, it mostly did.

The career ladder actually existed for you. You could start in the mailroom and end in the corner office. Companies hired you expecting to keep you for decades. They offered training, promotions, pensions. Loyalty was rewarded with security. You didn't job-hop because there was no reason to—staying meant rising, and rising meant stability for your family.

Your generation invented the sixty-hour workweek as a badge of honor. You competed by outworking everyone. Long hours weren't exploitation; they were dedication. You climbed by showing up first and leaving last, by saying yes to every assignment, by proving you wanted it more than the other guy. This worked because the other side of the bargain held: companies that demanded your time gave you raises, promotions, retirement.

You peaked professionally in your forties and fifties—the decades when Boomers ran everything. CEOs, partners, senators, judges, generals. Your generation held the levers of power so long that it started to seem natural. You made the rules. You set the expectations. You decided what success looked like, and it looked a lot like you.

Manufacturing left on your watch. The factories that built the middle class moved overseas, chasing cheaper labor. You saw it happen and adapted—into services, into management, into industries that required degrees rather than union cards. The workers who couldn't adapt were left behind. That's not entirely your fault, but it's part of your legacy.

Retirement came with a pension if you worked for the right company, Social Security that should last your lifetime, and whatever you saved in IRAs and 401(k)s. You might have retired at sixty-five, maybe earlier with a good package. You own your house outright. Your kids are grown. You have time for golf, travel, grandchildren. This is the retirement younger generations study like an artifact from a lost civilization.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when asking someone out meant walking up to them and using words, out loud, in front of other people? When getting a girl's phone number was a victory even though calling it meant talking to her father first? When a date meant picking her up at the door, shaking her dad's hand, and having her home by eleven?

You came of age during the sexual revolution. The pill became legal when you were fourteen. 'Free love' became a slogan when you were sixteen. Everything your parents believed about courtship—waiting until marriage, proper introductions, chaperoned dates—was suddenly negotiable. Some of you embraced the revolution. Some of you didn't. Most of you fell somewhere in between, figuring it out as the rules changed beneath your feet.

Courtship happened at drive-in movies, at diners with jukeboxes, at school dances where chaperones watched for hands in the wrong places. You went steady, exchanged class rings, carved initials into trees. Long-distance relationships meant expensive phone calls and letters you wrote by hand on actual paper. You couldn't text that you were running late. You just showed up late and hoped she was still waiting.

Your generation married younger than your children did—mid-twenties was typical, early twenties wasn't unusual. You also divorced at higher rates than any generation before. Whether that's a sign of dysfunction or a sign that people finally had options depends on your perspective. The stigma around divorce faded in your lifetime, making room for second chances that previous generations didn't get.

You've maintained friendships across decades without social media, without group chats, without any passive way to stay connected. Just phone calls on birthdays, Christmas cards in December, reunions every five or ten years. You remember when friendship required effort—when you had to actually reach out, actually show up, actually maintain the relationship through intention rather than algorithm.

Relationships in your generation were built on presence. You showed up at weddings, funerals, hospital rooms. You knew your neighbors' names, borrowed cups of sugar, watched each other's kids. Community was geography, not hashtags. The relationships that lasted did so because someone put in the work, year after year, without any digital reminders to do so.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three words shaped your financial psychology before you could spell them: your parents survived the Depression. They told you about bread lines, about Hoovervilles, about meals of onions and potatoes because that's all there was. They taught you that security matters more than status, that savings matter more than spending, that the floor can fall out without warning.

At twenty-two, the oil embargo taught you that gas prices could double overnight. At twenty-eight, Volcker's Fed raised interest rates to twenty percent to kill inflation—good for savings, brutal for anyone with a mortgage. At thirty-six, Black Monday crashed the stock market twenty-two percent in a single day. You've seen volatility. You've also seen recovery. That pattern taught you patience: don't panic, stay invested, things come back.

Your financial life unfolded in an era of accessible prosperity. A median house cost roughly three times the median income, not eight or ten times. College tuition at a state school could be covered by a summer job. One income could support a family, buy a house, fund retirement. This wasn't exceptional budgeting. It was just how the math worked.

The numbers tell the story. You bought houses for fifty or sixty thousand dollars that are now worth half a million or more. You invested in stocks that split and split again. You earned pensions that guaranteed income until death—benefits that companies stopped offering to workers who came after you. You accumulated wealth the old-fashioned way: buying when things were cheap, holding while they appreciated, retiring before the rules changed.

The numbers told a certain story when you were building wealth. Housing was attainable—three times annual income, not eight or ten. Interest rates fluctuated but down payments were manageable. Your financial journey unfolded during an era when the basic arithmetic of middle-class prosperity still added up.

Now you're managing preservation, not accumulation. Healthcare costs that can evaporate savings. Long-term care expenses that dwarf most retirement accounts. The calculation shifts from growing wealth to protecting it—and deciding how much to enjoy versus how much to leave behind.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your deepest blind spot is the assumption that the conditions you experienced were normal rather than historically specific. The path you walked—affordable education, stable employment, housing within reach—felt like the default state of things. Recognizing that it was a particular moment in economic history, not a universal baseline, requires stepping outside your own experience. That's difficult for anyone.

You trust institutions that have spent decades proving themselves untrustworthy. Government, corporations, churches, media—you grew up when these institutions mostly worked, mostly told the truth, mostly deserved the benefit of the doubt. You're genuinely baffled when younger people treat them with suspicion. But those younger people watched the Iraq War based on lies, the 2008 collapse based on fraud, the church scandals, the corporate bailouts. Their cynicism isn't attitude. It's evidence-based.

Your generation protested in the sixties, then elected Reagan in the eighties. You marched for civil rights, then moved to suburbs that zoning laws kept segregated. You dropped acid and preached peace, then became the toughest-on-crime voters in American history. The gap between the values you espoused at twenty and the policies you supported at fifty is wider than you'd like to admit. Younger generations notice.

Technology frustrates you in ways you sometimes can't articulate. It's not that you can't learn—you've learned plenty in seventy-plus years. It's that you don't always see the point. You survived without smartphones, without social media, without constant connectivity. You know, from lived experience, that life worked fine before all this. That knowledge is valuable. But it can also make you dismiss changes that genuinely matter to people who came after you.

You're so used to being in charge that other perspectives can feel like noise. Your generation has run things—corporations, governments, institutions—for so long that it seems natural. When younger workers want different things—flexibility, mental health days, work-life balance—you see softness where they see sanity. Both views contain truth. But hearing the other side requires listening, and listening requires stepping back from the center stage you've occupied for sixty years.

Maybe the hardest blind spot: you see yourself as you were at twenty-five—idealistic, questioning, ready to change the world—rather than as you are now, holding most of the wealth and power in a society where your grandchildren struggle to afford rent. The radical became the establishment. It happens to everyone eventually. Seeing it clearly is the work of wisdom.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1971-1981): Vietnam was winding down when you turned twenty—the last combat troops left when you were twenty-two. You entered the workforce during oil crises and stagflation, not the best conditions, but there were jobs to be had and they came with benefits. You got married, probably, in your mid-twenties. Bought a house for less than a new car costs today. Started a family as disco gave way to punk gave way to whatever came next. The Me Decade, they called it, as if self-discovery was something to apologize for.

Your 30s (1981-1991): The Reagan years. Morning in America. The economy recovered from the malaise of the seventies, and your career accelerated with it. Your kids grew up watching Transformers and G.I. Joe, playing Atari and Nintendo. You climbed the corporate ladder that still existed, earned promotions that came with real raises, paid down the mortgage on a house that kept appreciating. The Berlin Wall fell when you were thirty-eight—the Cold War you'd grown up with ended not with a bang but with sledgehammers and champagne.

Your 40s (1991-2001): Your prime earning decade. The Clinton years brought budget surpluses and tech bubbles. The internet arrived and you wondered if it mattered. (It did.) Your kids left for college, your parents started declining, and you became the sandwich generation—managing up and down, responsible for everyone. You hit career peaks: corner offices, executive titles, seats at tables where decisions were made. You were running things now, and things were going well.

Your 50s (2001-2011): September 11 happened when you were fifty. The towers fell, the wars started, the certainties of the nineties evaporated. The housing bubble inflated and then, spectacularly, exploded. Your 401(k) lost half its value in 2008. Retirement plans got pushed back. Some of you lost jobs in your mid-fifties, the worst possible timing. The economy that had worked for you suddenly stopped working, though not as badly for you as for those trying to enter it.

Your 60s (2011-2021): Recovery, gradual and uneven. The markets came back, your investments rebounded, retirement became possible again. You watched grandchildren arrive. You buried parents, maybe friends, faced mortality in ways that felt newly urgent. Some of you retired. Others discovered you couldn't afford to, or didn't want to. You stayed in the workforce longer than your parents did, partly by choice, partly by necessity.

Your 70s and beyond (2021+): You're here now, navigating a world that changes faster than you'd like. COVID hit your generation hardest—the death tolls, the isolation, the fear. Healthcare becomes central to daily life. Mobility requires attention. Independence demands maintenance. You've outlived your parents' life expectancy by a decade, thanks to medicine. You'll see great-grandchildren, tell stories about rotary phones and Vietnam, watch the world become unrecognizable. The future belongs to others now. Your job is to share what you learned getting here.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're one of roughly 3.8 million Americans born in 1951. The full Baby Boomer generation spans 76 million people—the demographic giant that reshaped every institution, every market, every election simply through sheer numbers.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They survived the Depression as children, fought World War II or Korea as young adults, and kept their heads down as middle-aged workers. They followed rules, respected authority, expected less. You questioned everything. You protested, experimented, demanded explanations. They were grateful for stability. You expected transformation. They think you're entitled. You think they were too accepting. Both views contain truth.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They grew up in your shadow, the forgotten middle child of American generations. Too small to move the demographic needle, too cynical from watching your idealism curdle into Reaganism. They got the jobs you didn't want, the housing after prices rose, the economy after you'd extracted the easy gains. They've spent their careers waiting for you to retire so they could finally run something. They're still waiting.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): They're your children, mostly, and they're not doing as well as you did at their age. When Boomers were in their forties, your generation controlled 21% of national wealth. Millennials at the same age control 7%. They graduated into the Great Recession, accumulated crushing student debt for degrees you got cheaply, and watched housing prices soar beyond reach. The math that worked for you doesn't work for them. Neither side likes admitting this.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Your grandchildren's generation. They've never known a world without internet, without school shooting drills, without climate change as an existential threat. They look at the future you're leaving them and they're not grateful—they're angry, or scared, or both. The cultural references that shaped your identity mean nothing to them. You might as well be speaking different languages. In many ways, you are.

Your life expectancy at birth was around 68 years. Now, if you've made it this far, you can expect to reach 85 or beyond. You've gained nearly two decades that previous generations didn't get. You've used them—traveling, working, consuming, influencing. Your generation refuses to fade quietly. You've always been the main character of American life. You're not interested in becoming a supporting player, even now.
